Interactive

Nebula Arena

Immersive launch experience for a physics puzzle game, blending R3F motion with responsive storytelling.

Astro React Three Fiber Tailwind CSS Framer Motion

Role

Lead engineer and motion designer

Outcome

Bounce rate dropped by 34%, and the launch waitlist filled in 72 hours thanks to the interactive walkthrough.

Key metrics

  • Visitors 38k in 10 days
  • Conversion 12.4% waitlist opt-in

Links

  • Design teardown ->
  • Repo ->

Overview

Players land in a launch bay where the arena comes alive: orbits trace neon rings, tops clash with subtle sparks, and the story unfolds as you scroll or flick through bays.

What I delivered

  • Built a physics-inspired hero experience with R3F and custom shader materials
  • Authored modular MDX content for the campaign timeline
  • Tuned performance to keep the initial payload under 140 KB gzipped

Behind the scenes

I prototyped the arena interactions with Framer Motion velocity tracking, then ported the math into React Three Fiber for a consistent motion language between DOM and WebGL layers.

Problem

The studio needed a performant teaser site that matched the kinetic feel of their gameplay without relying on heavy video files.

Insight

We could simulate the clash of spinning tops with lightweight procedural shaders and spring-based motion, keeping the bundle lean.

Approach

Astro for static output, React islands for the arena canvas, and a Tailwind-powered design system that mirrored the in-game arena surfaces.

Result

Bounce rate dropped by 34%, and the launch waitlist filled in 72 hours thanks to the interactive walkthrough.
